Preparation, characterization and use of poly(4-vinylpyridinium) perchlorate as a new, efficient, and versatile solid phase catalyst for acetylation of alcohols, phenols and amines Nader Ghaffari Khaligh Department of Chemistry, College of Science, University of Guilan, Rasht 41335-19141, Iran Graphical abstract Highlights ► Introducing new solid phase catalyst for organic transformations. ► Superiority of the catalyst with respect to the reported catalysts. ► Generality of the method, high yields and short reaction times. ► Application of solvent-free condition in the reaction and useful for industrial applications. Poly(4-vinylpyridine) perchlorate, is a supported, recyclable, eco-benign catalyst for the reaction acetylation of structurally diverse alcohols, phenols and amines at room temperature under solvent-free conditions. The catalyst was studied by FT-IR, X-ray diffraction, Scanning Electron Microscope and Thermo-gravimetric Analyses. All the products were extensively characterized by 1H NMR, FT-IR, GC–MS and melting point analyses. The catalyst can be recovered and reused without loss of activity. The work-up of the reaction consists of a simple filtration, followed by concentration of the crude product and purification. It is important to point out that a large-scale reaction is possible using a same amount of catalyst. Keywords Solid acid Poly(4-vinylpyridinium) perchlorate Acetylation Phenols Alcohols Amines 1 Introduction In recent years, the development of heterogeneous catalysts have become a major area of research in synthetic organic chemistry due to some potential advantages of these material over homogeneous systems such as simplified recovery, reusability, enhanced selectivity and reactivity, easy product isolation and incorporation in continuous reactors and microreactors [1]. This can lead to novel and environmentally benign chemical procedures for academia and industry [2]. Application of solid acids in organic transformation has important roles, because these reagents do less harm to environment and have no corrosion or disposal of effluent problems. As economically and ecologically benign catalysts, their research and application have attracted much attention in chemistry and industry [3–9]. There are more than 100 industrial processes using over 103 solid acids as catalysts [10]. It is clear that green chemistry not only requires the use of environmentally benign reagents and solvents, but also the recovery and reuse of the catalyst. One way to overcome the problem of recyclability of the traditional acid catalyst is to chemically anchor the reactive center onto a large surface area solid carrier [11]. In these types of solids, the reactive centers are highly mobile similar to homogeneous catalysts and at the same time these species have the advantage of being recyclable in the same fashion as heterogeneous catalysts. Functional polymers have the potential advantages of small molecules with the same functional groups [12]. Poly(4-vinylpyridine) is an interesting material because of its stable pyridyl group and ability to form charge transfer complex with acidic dopants [13]. Poly(4-vinylpyridine) seems to an attractive support to immobilize mineral acids because of the basic nature of pyridyl group. The prevalence of alcohol, phenol and amine functionalities in drugs and pharmaceuticals makes the protection of these functional groups a prime importance while carrying out reactions sensitive to such functionalities in a multifunctional substrate having one or more of these groups [14]. Protection is usually achieved through acylation with anhydrides due to the ease of deprotection [15,16]. The poor nucleophilicity of hydroxylic compounds, particularly phenols, makes it essential to activate the anhydride. Recent procedures for acylation with anhydride include the use of DMAP and 4-pyrolidinopyridine [17], TMEDA [18], Bu3P [19], iodine [20], p-toluenesulfonic acid [21], alumina [22], zinc chloride [23], cobalt chloride [24], montmorillonit K-10 and KSF [25], zeolite HSZ-360 [26], zirconium sulfophenyl phosphonate [27], Sc(OTf)3 [28], TaCl5 [29], trimethylsilyl trifluoromethanesulfonate (TMSOTf) [30], Cu(OTf)2 [31], In(OTf)3 [32], Ce(OTf)3 [33], magnesium bromide [34], Bi(OTf)3 [35], ferric perchlorate adsorbed on silica-gel [36], Mg(ClO4)2 [37], RuCl3 [38], InCl3 [39], ZrCl4 [40], Cp2ZrCl2 [41], and cerium polyoxometalate [42]. The limitations of the existing protocols realized in terms of longer reaction time, stringent conditions, use of halogenated solvents, use of hazardous materials, use of costly and water sensitive catalysts, special efforts required to prepare the catalyst, need to use excess acylating agent, potential side reactions with acid sensitive substrates and in most of the cases being applicable to alcohols only make the necessity to develop a better acylation method in high demand. Moreover, the increasing pressure from environmentalists has led to a search for more friendly forms of catalysis. The leading contender for an environmentally acceptable alternative to the acylation processes is the use of supported solid acids. The activity and selectivity of a reagent dispersed on the surface of a support is improved as the effective surface area of the reagent can be increased up to one hundred times. The fact that supported solid acids have good thermal and mechanical stabilities, can be easily handled as they are invariably low toxic, non-corrosive free flowing powders and are easily separated from the reaction mixture through filtration and reused make them suitable for industrial applications. The acetylation of acid-sensitive substrates catalyzed by aqueous HClO4 led to the formation of rearranged products. We reasoned that the large negative H 0 value [43] might be the reason for the potential competitive side reactions with acid-sensitive substrates during the use of a strong protic acid. Herein, we planned to evaluate its catalytic activity HClO4 supported on poly(4-vinylpyridine). We report the successful synthesis of poly(4-vinylpyridinium) perchlorate [P(4-VPH)ClO4], the characterization and application as simple reusable solid acid catalyst in acetylation of alcohols, phenols and amines at room temperature under solvent-free conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material Unless specified, all chemicals were analytical grade and purchased from Merck, Aldrich and Fluka Chemical Companies and used without further purification. Products were characterized by their physical constant and comparison with authentic samples. The purity determination of the substrates and reaction monitoring were accompanied by TLC using silica gel SIL G/UV 254 plates. 2.2 Instrumentation The purity determination of the products was accomplished by GC–MS on an Agilent GC-Mass-6890 instrument under 70eV conditions. The IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin Elmer 781 Spectrophotometer using KBr pellets for solid and neat for liquid samples in the range of 4000–400cm−1. The UV spectra were recorded on an Agilent 8453 UV–vis spectrophotometer at room temperature. In all the cases the 1H NMR spectra were recorded with Bruker Avance 400 or 300MHz instrument using. 13C NMR data were collected on Bruker Avance 100 or 75MHz instrument. All chemical shifts are quoted in parts per million (ppm) relative to TMS using deuterated solvent. Microanalyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240-B microanalyzer. Melting points were recorded on a Büchi B-545 apparatus in open capillary tubes. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed at room temperature on a Philips PW1830 generator X-ray powder diffractometer, using Ni filter and Co-Kα radiation (λ =1.542Å). The scanning was over a range of 2θ =10–70°. The SEM analyses were carried out using a JEOL JSM-6390LV Scanning Electron Microscope equipped with an Energy-Dispersive X-ray analyzer (EDX). Thermal stability of the supported catalysts was examined by SHIMADZU Thermo-gravimetric Analyzer-50 (TGA) in the temperature range of 20–700°C. All measurements were conducted under nitrogen. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm analysis was carried out at liquid nitrogen temperature (77K) on a Quantachrome ChemBet 3000 apparatus; samples were degassed for 2h at 110°C prior to analysis. The analytical data were processed by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation for surface areas. 2.3 Catalysts preparation HClO4 (1.8ml, 30mmol, as a 70% aqueous solution) was added to the suspension of powdered P(4-VP) (5.0g) [poly(4-vinylpyridine cross-linked with 2% DVB∼60mesh, MW: 60,000; Fluka Chemica] in Et2O. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 8h then the suspension was concentrated and the residue was successively washed with Et2O. After removal of water and ether in a rotary evaporator, the solid powder was dried at 50°C for 24h under vacuum to afford P(4-VPH)ClO4 6.23g (2.5mmolg−1) as a free flowing powder (Scheme 1 ). 2.4 Characterization of catalyst 2.4.1 FTIR studies Fig. 1 presents the FTIR spectra of P(4-VP) and P(4-VPH)ClO4. FTIR spectra can be used as a powerful technique for the investigation of interaction between perchloric acid and P(4-VP) support. As shown in this figure, presence of an extra hydrogen atom on the pyridine nitrogen in the P(4-VPH)ClO4 increased the number of vibrational modes and brought completely different FTIR spectrum [44–47]. P(4-VPH)ClO4 exhibited characteristic absorption bands at 1100.71, 1062.70 [ν asym(ClO4)], 628.60 [ν sym(ClO4)] and 463.78 [δ sym(ClO4)]cm−1 which are assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric ClO4 stretching and bending vibrations, respectively [48–50]. The characteristic stretching of pyridine rings occurs at 1598.88, 1554.52 and 1450.37cm−1 for pure P(4-VP) and at 825.48cm−1, to the single-substituted pyridine ring. However, in presence of H+ ions (from perchloric acid) the vibration mode at 1598.88cm−1 is shifted to 1639.38cm−1 suggesting formation pyridinium cation [51]. In addition, a broad, intense band centered around 3419.56cm−1 [ν(OH)] and a weak absorption as shoulder at 1630.32cm−1 [δ(H2O)] indicate the presence of water (Fig. 1). 2.4.2 X-ray diffraction studies X-ray diffraction studies were performed for P(4-VP) and P(4-VPH)ClO4 solid acid and the obtained diffractograms are displayed in Fig. 2 . It should be noted that P(4-VP) and P(4-VPH)ClO4 were dried at 100°C before analysis. Incorporation of HClO4 leads to some changes in the diffractogram of P(4-VP). In the diffractogram of P(4-VP) two broad reflexes centered at 2θ around 20.5° and 41.5° appear. Thus, the polymer is a crystalline polymer [52]. After protonation of P(4-VP) by HClO4 the position of the first peak is changed (2θ around 23°) and its intensity strongly is reduced, and the broad peak at 2θ (around 41.5°) is disappeared. These observations imply that the crystalline nature of P(4-VP) is not changed but crystalline size of P(4-VP) is decreased after modification with perchloric acid. 2.4.3 Thermal analysis Fig. 3 provides the TGA curves of P(4-VP) (left) [53] and P(4-VPH)ClO4 (right) under nitrogen. The TGA curve of pure P(4-VP) displayed a weight loss ca. 10% between 80°C and 100°C which is corresponding to the loss of the physically adsorbed water and bonded H2O within the gallery of P(4-VP). A second and total weight loss process took place at the temperature range 400–470°C [53]. P(4-VPH)ClO4 was degraded mainly by a four-stage process. The first weight loss which is observed at approximately 100°C, attributed to the loss of moisture contents. For P(4-VPH)ClO4, the main degradation stage starts at ca. 285°C and finishes at ca. 300°C with a augmentation in its intensity at 290°C (see Fig. 3). In this temperature range the degradation of both poly(4-vinylpyridinium) group and perchlorate ion occurs (ca. 61%). Therefore, P(4-VPH)ClO4 is less thermally-stable than P(4-VP) as evidenced by the lowering in the initial temperature of degradation from ca. 400°C for P(4-VP) to ca. 290°C for P(4-VPH)ClO4. The reduction in degradation temperature is probably due to protonation of the pyridine rings with H+ ions which induces significant changes in the electronic density of the ring. This can be observed in the displacement of CN stretching in the pyridyl ring for larger wavenumbers (see Fig. 1). These electronic density changes can provoke a weakening of the chemical bonds in the pyridine ring and polymeric backbone chain with a consequent reduction in thermal stability [51b]. 2.4.4 SEM and BET analysis SEM with EDX technique was used for studying the morphology of the solid samples. In the SEM micrograph of P(4-VP) sample, it can be observed that the P(4-VP) is formed by agglomerates of grains with smooth surface [54]. The SEM micrographs of catalyst showed that with chemical modification the primary structure of P(4-VP) was changed (Fig. 4 ). As seen in SEM images (Fig. 4C and D), it can be concluded that the particles produced for P(4-VPH)ClO4 have irregular shapes with some degree of porous surface that will aid in adsorption. This increased the catalytic activity of the catalyst in reaction. The surface area of pure P(4-VP) and P(4-VPH)ClO4 were calculated from liquid nitrogen adsorption using the BET equation. After protonation with perchloric acid, P(4-VPH)ClO4 exhibits a larger specific surface area in comparison to those of pure P(4-VP), the BET surface area increases from 510 to 856m2 g−1, which can be due to the modification on the surface of polymer P(4-VP) as seen in Fig. 4C and D. 2.4.5 Acidity of the catalyst The Hammett acidity function–activity relationship can effectively express the acidity strength of an acid in organic solvents [55–57]. It can be calculated by the equation below: H 0 = pK ( I ) aq + log [ I ] s [ IH + ] s Here, “I” represents the indicator base (mainly substituted dinitroanilines), [IH+]s and [I]s are respectively the molar concentrations of the protonated and unprotonated forms of the indicator. The pK(I)aq values are already known (for example the pK(I)aq value of 4-nitroaniline is 0.99) and can be obtained from many references. According to Lambert–Beer's Law, the value of [I]s/[IH+]s can be determined and calculated through UV–visible spectrum. In our experiment, 4-nitroaniline was chosen as the basic indicator and CH2Cl2 as the solvent because it is aprotic. The maximal absorbance of unprotonated form of 4-nitroaniline was observed at 330nm in CH2Cl2 (Fig. 5 ). The results obtained are listed in Table 1 , which show the acidity strength of P(4-VPH)ClO4. The capacity of P(4-VPH)ClO4 was determined by gravimetric and potentiometric titration methods and it was found to be 0.82–0.86mmol ClO4 per gram of poly(4-vinylpyridinium) perchlorate polymer [58,59]. 2.5 Typical procedure of acetylation The substrate (alcohol, phenol or amine; 1.0mmol) was treated with Ac2O (2.0mmol) in the presence of P(4-VPH)ClO4 (50mg) at room temperature under solvent-free conditions and magnetic stirring. After completion of the reaction as indicated by TLC, the mixture was diluted with Et2O (25ml) and the catalyst allowed to settle down. The supernatant ethereal solution was decanted off, the catalyst washed with Et2O (2ml) and the combined ethereal solution concentrated under vacuum to afford the product, identical (mp, IR, 1H and 13C NMR, and GC–MS) to an authentic sample of acetylated product. The recovered catalyst was dried at 50°C under vacuum for 2h. The recovered catalyst, after drying, was reused for four more consecutive acetylation reactions of benzyl alcohol (1.0mmol) affording 96, 96, 94, and 94% yields, respectively, in 22, 23, 23, and 25min (Scheme 2 ). 2.6 The spectral data of some representative and new products Benzoin acetate (Table 3, entry 14): IR (neat) ν =1738, 1697cm−1; 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400MHz): δ =2.23 (s, 3H), 6.84 (s, 1H), 7.32–7.53 (m, 8H), 7.95 (d, J =8.8Hz, 2H); 13C (CDCl3, 100MHz) δ =20.1, 77.2, 128.2, 128.3, 128.6, 128.8, 133.1, 133.1, 134.1, 169.9, 193.3ppm. N-(2-Acetoxyphenyl) acetamide ( Table 3 , entry 32): IR (neat) ν =3320, 1730, 1682cm−1; 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400MHz): δ =2.16 (s, 3H), 2.36 (s, 3H), 7.14–7.17 (m, 2H), 7.22–7.25 (m, 1H), 7.39 (br s, 1H), 8.11 (d, J =7.6Hz, 1H)ppm; 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100MHz): δ =20.6, 22.7, 117.8, 120.7, 123.9, 125.9, 130.7, 140.5, 167.0, 167.9ppm. 3 Results and discussion In continuation of our ongoing research program on the development of new catalysts and methods for organic transformations [60–63], earlier report from our laboratory described the environmentally benign synthesis of poly(4-vinylpyridinium) hydrogen sulfate [P(4-VPH)HSO4] and the application in chemoselective 1,1-diacetate protection and deprotection of aldehydes [60], the synthesis of 14-aryl-14H-dibenzo[a,j]xanthenes under conventional heating and ultrasound irradiation [61], synthesis of 12-aryl-12H-indeno[1,2-b]naphtho[3,2-e]pyran-5,11,13-triones [62]. Herein, we planned to evaluate its catalytic activity HClO4 supported on poly(4-vinylpyridine). The structure of P(4-VPH)ClO4 assured us to accept that this reagent can act as an efficient solid acid catalyst in reactions that need mild acidic reagents to speed up. Our investigations clarified that this prediction is correct and acetylation of alcohols, phenols and amines with Ac2O efficiently promoted in the presence of P(4-VPH)ClO4 (Scheme 3 ). The reaction for preparation of catalyst is easy and clean and needs no special workup procedure (Scheme 1). In order to standardize the reaction, different amounts of P(4-VPH)ClO4 was used to get benzyl acetate from benzyl alcohol and acetic anhydride at room temperature under solvent-free conditions, and the results are summarized in Table 2 . It is clear that, the reaction can be carried out in the presence of catalytic amount of P(4-VPH)ClO4 and the yields are excellent, it was found that the reaction is not possible without catalyst. After these preliminary experiments, catalytic amount of P(4-VPH)ClO4 (50mg) was used to convert a variety of functionalized alcohols, phenols and amines with acetic anhydride into respective esters and amides at room temperature under solvent-free conditions, and the results are presented in Table 3 . The results incorporated in Table 3 demonstrate the generality and scope of P(4-VPH)ClO4 during the acetylation of structurally diverse alcohols, phenols and amines. The reaction could be carried out with 2equiv. of Ac2O at room temperature in 12–55min. Benzylic alcohols bearing electron-donating groups (Table 3, entries 2, 3, 4, 7 and 8) reacted same as benzyl alcohol (Table 3, entry 1), while acetylation of benzyl alcohols having electron-withdrawing were sluggish and the corresponding ester isolated in only 78–83% yield after 55min at room temperature under solvent-free conditions (Table 3, entries 5 and 6). It is important to note that benzyl alcohol reacted with Ac2O without any catalyst in long reaction times and only near 24% conversion (Table 2, entry 1). Sterically hindered and electron deficient alcohols (Table 3, entries 5, 6, 12, 14, 15 and 16) are efficiently acetylated under solvent-free conditions. Excellent selectivity was observed in that secondary and tertiary alcohols do not experience any competitive dehydration (Table 3, entries 9–16). In order to elucidate the mildness and stereospecificity of the P(4-VPH)HClO4 catalyzed acetylation of alcohols, the reaction of optically active L(−)-Menthol and R(+)-Borneol were studied with P(4-VPH)HClO4 (Table 3, entries 12 and 16). We observed that L(−)-Menthol ([α]D =−49.0°, c =10 in 95% ethanol, 99% e.e.) and R(+)-Borneol ([α]D =+37.9°, c =5 in ethanol, 99% e.e.) react enantioselectivity with retention of configuration on the benzylic center to provide L-(−)-Menthyl acetate ([α]D =−73.0°, neat, 98% e.e.) and (+)-Bornyl acetate ([α]D =+41.8°, neat, 98% e.e.). The highest optical purity was obtained in an enantiopure form in high yield and under high regioselectivity by using P(4-VPH)HClO4 at room temperature under solvent-free conditions. The optical rotation of the product was determined and compared with that reported from Aldrich. Also, we extended the use of P(4-VPH)ClO4 for direct acetylation of amines (Table 3, entries 24–28) with Ac2O. The superiority of solid acid is further established in the fact that direct acetylation of amines with Ac2O (2equiv.) could be achieved in 5–20min at room temperature (86–96% yields) under the catalytic influence of P(4-VPH)ClO4 (50mg). Our protocol has some advantage because the two functional groups were acetylated with together during the reaction conditions (Table 3, entries 29–32). The catalyst was recovered and reused five consecutive times giving excellent yields. Use of solid acid catalysts suffers from some disadvantages such as ‘leaching’ that leads to loss of activity. The leaching of perchloric acid into the liquid phase was rigorously checked by potentiometric and conductometric techniques [57,58] after every run and also we compare FTIR of fresh catalyst with recovered catalyst after fifth run. The results showed no leaching of HClO4 during the reaction. We have compared the obtained results in the acetylation of benzyl alcohol with acetic anhydride catalyzed by P(4-VPH)ClO4 with some of those reported in the literature. It is clear that based on Table 4 , some methods are superior in terms of reaction time, catalyst amount, or product yield. However, here we describe one or more of the limitations of the existing protocols such use of halogenated catalysts, use of hazardous materials, use of costly catalysts (e.g. the triflates). Although the triflates, in general, are claimed as the most effective catalysts, the larger negative H 0 value (−14.1) of TfOH [43] suggests that metal triflates should be very strong Lewis acids [64] and lead to competitive side reactions (e.g. dehydration and rearrangement etc.) for acid sensitive substrates. We are currently engaged in mechanistic studies to understand the precise role of the P(4-VPH)ClO4, although the actual mechanism of the reaction was not clear, but based on the literature [30b,39,65,66], the mechanism shown in Scheme 4 was selected as the most probable one. Acetic anhydride is first activated by acidic sites on poly(4-vinylpyridinium) cation to afford (I). Alcohol, phenol and amine attacks (I) which in turn converts to the final product and releases P(4-VPH)ClO4 for the next catalytic cycle. The selectivity of this method was checked by competitive acetylation of benzyl alcohol, phenol and aniline with together. The results showed that aniline was acetylated selectively in the presence of benzyl alcohol and phenol (Table 5 , entries 1 and 2). This may be considered as a useful practical achievement in acetylation amines in presence of alcohols and phenols. Also benzyl alcohol was acetylated selectively in presence of phenol in 88:12% yields, respectively (Table 5, entry 3). Notably, we have noticed that the conversion of benzyl alcohol to the respective acetate product can be carried out even in a larger scale (20mmol) in 92% yield within 25min without any difficulty by using 50mg of solid acid. Therefore, it indicates that a large-scale reaction is possible using a same amount of catalyst. It is important to point out that the present method is much cleaner, does not involve any chromatographic separation for a large-scale reaction. 4 Conclusions P(4-VPH)ClO4 is a new and highly efficient catalyst for acetylation of alcohols, phenols and amines. The low cost, ease of handling and, with increasing environmental concern [67], the solvent-free conditions employed in the present method, which make it “environmentally friendly” and useful for industrial applications. The protocol is highly chemoselective offering potential in different applications. The methodology also has several other advantages such as: high to excellent yields, no side reactions, ease of preparation and handling of the catalyst, cost efficiency and effective reusability of the catalyst, use of inexpensive catalyst and simple experimental procedure. Further work to explore this novel catalyst in other organic transformations is in progress. coredata.dc:description: Poly(4-vinylpyridine) perchlorate, is a supported, recyclable, eco-benign catalyst for the reaction acetylation of structurally diverse alcohols, phenols and amines at room temperature under solvent-free conditions. The catalyst was studied by FT-IR, X-ray diffraction, Scanning Electron Microscope and Thermo-gravimetric Analyses. All the products were extensively characterized by 1H NMR, FT-IR, GC–MS and melting point analyses. The catalyst can be recovered and reused without loss of activity. The work-up of the reaction consists of a simple filtration, followed by concentration of the crude product and purification. It is important to point out that a large-scale reaction is possible using a same amount of catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation, characterization and use of poly(4-vinylpyridinium) perchlorate as a new, efficient, and versatile solid phase catalyst for acetylation of alcohols, phenols and amines
